title: The $q$-tangent and $q$-secant numbers via continued fractions

title_detail.value: The $q$-tangent and $q$-secant numbers via continued fractions

summary:
It is well known that the $(-1)$-evaluation of the enumerator polynomials of
permutations (resp. derangements) by the number of excedances gives rise to
tangent numbers (resp. secant numbers). Recently, two distinct $q$-analogues of
the latter result have been discovered by Foata and Han, and Josuat-Verg\`es,
respectively. In this paper, we will prove some general continued fractions
expansions formulae, which permits us to give a unified treatment of
Josuat-Verg\`es' two formulae and also to derive a new $q$-analogue of the
aforementioned formulae. Our approach is based on a $(p,q)$-analogue of tangent
and secant numbers via continued fractions and also the generating function of
permutations with respect to the quintuple statistic consisting of fixed point
number, weak excedance number, crossing number, nesting number and inversion
number. We also give a combinatorial proof of Josuat-Verg\`es' formulae by
using a new linear model of derangements.

summary_detail.value:
It is well known that the $(-1)$-evaluation of the enumerator polynomials of
permutations (resp. derangements) by the number of excedances gives rise to
tangent numbers (resp. secant numbers). Recently, two distinct $q$-analogues of
the latter result have been discovered by Foata and Han, and Josuat-Verg\`es,
respectively. In this paper, we will prove some general continued fractions
expansions formulae, which permits us to give a unified treatment of
Josuat-Verg\`es' two formulae and also to derive a new $q$-analogue of the
aforementioned formulae. Our approach is based on a $(p,q)$-analogue of tangent
and secant numbers via continued fractions and also the generating function of
permutations with respect to the quintuple statistic consisting of fixed point
number, weak excedance number, crossing number, nesting number and inversion
number. We also give a combinatorial proof of Josuat-Verg\`es' formulae by
using a new linear model of derangements.

author: Jiang Zeng
fulltext:
THE q-TANGENT AND q-SECANT NUMBERS VIA CONTINUED
FRACTIONS

arXiv:0911.4658v3 [math.CO] 22 Apr 2010

HEESUNG SHIN AND JIANG ZENG

Abstract. It is well known that the (−1)-evaluation of the enumerator polynomials of
permutations (resp. derangements) by the number of excedances gives rise to tangent numbers (resp. secant numbers). Recently, two distinct q-analogues of the latter result have
been discovered by Foata and Han, and Josuat-Vergès, respectively. In this paper, we will
prove some general continued fractions expansions formulae, which permits us to give a unified treatment of Josuat-Vergès' two formulae and also to derive a new q-analogue of the
aforementioned formulae. Our approach is based on a (p, q)-analogue of tangent and secant
numbers via continued fractions and also the generating function of permutations with respect to the quintuple statistic consisting of fixed point number, weak excedance number,
crossing number, nesting number and inversion number. We also give a combinatorial proof
of Josuat-Vergès' formulae by using a new linear model of derangements.

Contents
1. Introduction
2. A (p, q)-analogue of tangent and secant numbers
3. Two equidistributed quintuple statistics
4. Counting permutations by the quintuple statistics
5. The analytic proof of Theorems 2 and 3
6. The combinatorial proof of Theorem 2
6.1. Involution φ on Sn
6.2. Involution ψ on D∗n
7. A parity-independent formula for q-Euler numbers
Acknowledgement

Key words and phrases. (p, q)-Euler numbers, q-Eulerian polynomials, alternating permutations, Dyck path
diagrams, Laguerre history, Françon-Viennot bijectiion, Foata-Zeilberger bijection.

HEESUNG SHIN AND JIANG ZENG

1. Introduction
The tangent numbers E2n+1 (n ≥ 0) and secant numbers E2n (n ≥ 1) are the coefficients
in the Taylor expansions of the tangent and secant:

Let Sn be the set of permutations of [n] := {1, 2, . . . , n}. A permutation σ = σ1 σ2 * * * σn ∈ Sn
is alternating (resp. falling alternating) permutation if σ1 < σ2 , σ2 > σ3 , σ3 < σ4 , etc. (resp.
σ1 > σ2 , σ2 < σ3 , σ3 > σ4 , etc.). As proved by André [And79] in 1879, the number of
alternating permutations in Sn is En . Furthermore, an integer i ∈ [n] is called a fixed point
(resp. weak excedance, excedance) of σ if σi = i (resp. σi ≥ i, σi > i). Denote the number of
fixed points (resp. weak excedances, excedances) of σ by fix σ (resp. wex σ, exc σ). The joint
distribution of (exc, fix) was first computed by Foata and Schützenberger [FS70], who proved
the following formula (see also [KZ04] for another proof):

Remark. Since exc(σ) = n − wex(σ −1 ) for σ ∈ Sn , Eq. (10) reduces to (4) when q = 1.

 4

HEESUNG SHIN AND JIANG ZENG

Since (10) and (11) were proved by expanding the generating functions into continued
fractions and then identifying the continued fractions in [JV10], our first aim is then to
seek for a unified proof of Josuat-Vergès' theorem from a continued fraction formula for the
generating function of permutations with respect to the triple statistic (wex, fix, cros), which
should play the role of the Sherashian-Wachs formula in Foata-Han's proof. Actually we shall
prove some more general results (see Theorems 4, 8 and 9), which permit us to obtain a new
q-analogue of (4) and (5).
Theorem 3. For n ≥ 1, we have

Apart from the aforementioned analytic proof, Foata and Han [FH10] gave also a combinatorial proof of Theorem 1 making use of a linear model of derangements, called desarrangements. Similarly, we will provide a combinatorial proof of Theorem 2 using a new linear
model of derangements, i.e., called coderangements, which are permutations such that every
left-to-right maximum is a descent, see Definition 7.
The rest of this paper is organized as follows. In Section 2 we define a (p, q)-analogue of
Tangent and secant numbers as a refined counting of alternating permutations and show that
their generating functions have nice continued fraction expansions. In Sections 3, by applying
a bijection similar to that of Clarke-Steingrı́msson-Zeng [CSZ97], we obtain another quintuple
statistic equidistributed with (wex, fix, cros, nest, inv), which results in another combinatorial
interpretation of Theorem 2 (see (45) and (46)), that involves coderangements (see Definition 7). In Section 4 we will prove a continued fraction expansion for the generating function
of permutations with respect to the quadruple statistic (wex, fix, cros, nest, inv). Two special
cases of this formula will play the role of two q-analogues of Roselle's formula. We then derive
an analytic proof of Theorems 2 and 3 in Section 5. In Section 6, we will construct two killing
involutions using the latter interpretations to prove Theorems 2 as well as a combinatorial
proof for (13). Finally, we give a parity independent formula for the q-Euler numbers En (q)
in Section 7.
2. A (p, q)-analogue of tangent and secant numbers

It turns out that the generating functions of En (p, q) give rise to remarkable (p, q)-analogue
of the two continued fractions (8) and (9).
We first recall some well-known facts about the combinatorial theory of continued fractions.
A Motzkin path of length n is a sequence of lattice points si = (i, yi ) (i = 0, . . . , n) in the
plane Z2 such that
• yi ≥ 0 for all 1 ≤ i ≤ n − 1 and y0 = yn = 0.
• yi − yi−1 ∈ {−1, 0, 1}.
For i = 1, . . . , n, if yi − yi−1 = −1, 0 and 1 we shall say that the step (si−1 , si ) is of type ց,
−→, and ր, respectively, and call yi−1 the height of the step (si−1 , si ). Now, weight each step
(si−1 , si ) at height h by w(si−1 , si ) = ah (resp. bh , ch ) if the step (si−1 , si ) is
Q ր (resp. −→,
ց) and define the weight of the Motzkin path γ = s0 , s1 , . . . , sn by w(γ) = ni=1 w(si−1 , si ).
A Dyck path is a Motzkin path without step of type −→. So the length of a Dyck path must
be even. Let Mn (resp. D2n ) denote the set of Motzkin (resp. Dyck) paths of length n (resp.
2n). Then, it is well known (see [Fla80]) that

Remark. From the above continued fraction expansions it is clear that the (p, q)-Euler number En (p, q) is symmetric in p and q. This can also be seen combinatorially as follows:
For σ = σ1 . . . σn ∈ Sn , define its reverse to be σ R = σn . . . σ1 and its complement to be
σ̄ = (n + 1 − σ1 ) . . . (n + 1 − σn ). Clearly, if σ ∈ A2n , then σ̄ R ∈ A2n and (31-2, 2-31)σ =
(2-31, 31-2)σ̄ R ; if σ ∈ A2n+1 , then σ R ∈ A2n+1 and (31-2, 2-13)σ = (2-13, 31-2)σ R .
Letting p = 1 in (14) and (15), we recover the q-analogue of Euler number En studied by
Chebikin [Che08] and Han et al. [HRZ99]:

3. Two equidistributed quintuple statistics
Let σ = σ1 σ2 * * * σn ∈ Sn . If 1 ≤ i ≤ n − 1 and σi > σi+1 , the entry σi (resp. σi+1 ) is called
a descent or descent top (resp. descent bottom) of σ. For all i ∈ [n], the entry σi is called a
nondescent or nondescent top (resp. nondescent bottom) of σ, if it is not a descent or descent
top (resp. descent bottom) of σ. For σ ∈ Sn , let des σ be the number of descents in σ. Then
the number of nondescents in σ is ndes σ := n − des σ. For i = 1, . . . , n, the entry σi is called
a left-to-right maximum of σ if σi = max {σ1 , . . . , σi }.
Definition 7. A nondescent σi in σ (i = 1, . . . , n) is called a foremaximum of σ if σi is a leftto-right maximum in σ. Denote the number of foremaximum of σ by fmax σ. A permutation
σ is called coderangement if fmax σ = 0. Let D∗n be the subset of Sn of coderangements, that
is, D∗n = {σ ∈ Sn : fmax σ = 0}.

 THE q-TANGENT AND q-SECANT NUMBERS VIA CONTINUED FRACTIONS

9

For example, the foremaximums of 4157368 ∈ S8 are 5 and 8, hence
fmax(4157368) = 2 and D∗4 = {2143, 3142, 3241, 4123, 4132, 4213, 4231, 4312, 4321} .
Recall that for σ ∈ Sn the statistic MAD is defined by
MAD σ = des σ + (31-2) σ + 2 (2-31) σ.

(29)

Theorem 8. For n ≥ 1, there is a bijection Φ on Sn such that
(ndes, fmax, 31-2, 2-31, MAD)σ = (wex, fix, cros, nest, inv)Φ(σ)

for all σ ∈ Sn .

(30)

Remark. Roselle [Ros68] first studied the statistics (suc, ndes) on Sn , where suc σ is the
number of indices i ∈ [n] such that σi+1 = σi + 1 with σn+1 = n + 1. (A nondescent is called
a rise in his paper.) It is trivial that (suc, ndes) and (adj, des +1) are equidistributed on Sn
by
(suc, ndes)σ = (adj, des +1)σ̄,
where adj σ is the number of indices i ∈ [n] such that σi+1 = σi − 1 with σn+1 = 0.
Burnstein [Bur10] has recently given a new proof of Eriksen's result [Eri10], which states
that (adj, des +1) and (fix, wex) are equidistributed on Sn . Since our theorem implies that
(fmax, ndes) and (fix, wex) are equidistributed on Sn , (suc, ndes) and (fmax, ndes) are also
equidistributed on Sn . It would be interesting to make the involution on Sn keeping these
statistics.
In the literature, there are several bijections on Sn transforming 'linear statistics' to 'cyclic
statistics' on Sn . For example, the composition of the Françon-Viennot bijection ΨF V :
Sn → Ln in [FV79] and the inverse of the Foata-Zeilberer bijection ΨF Z : Sn → Ln in [FZ90]
transforms the number of descents to the number of excedances. A direct description of this
composition was given as ΦCSZ in [CSZ97]. It turns out that the composition of the mapping
σ 7→ σ −1 and the bijection ΦCSZ in [CSZ97] satisfies the condition (30). For the reader's
convenience, we give a direct description of the mapping Φ as that of ΦCSZ in [CSZ97]. For
k ∈ [n], define the right embracing number (2-31)k σ (resp. left embracing number (31-2) k σ)
of k in σ to be the number of integers l ∈ [n − 1] such that
σk−1 < l (resp. l + 1 < σk−1 )

and

σl > k > σl+1 .

For example, (2-31)4 (4723516) = 2 and (31-2)3 (4723516) = 1. An inversion top number (resp.
inversion bottom number) of a letter i in words π is the number of occurrences of inversions
of form (i, j) (resp (j, i)) in π. We now construct τ = Φ(σ) in such a way that
∀k = 1, . . . , n.


Given a permutation σ, we first construct two biwords, ff′ and gg′ , and then form the biword


τ = ff′ gg′ by concatenating f and g, and f ′ and g′ , respectively. The word f is defined as
the subword of descent bottoms in σ, ordered increasingly, and g is defined as the subword
of nondescent bottoms in σ, also ordered increasingly. The word f ′ is the permutation on
descent tops in σ such that the inversion bottom number of each letter a in f ′ is the right
embracing number of a in σ. Similarly, the word g′ is the permutation on nondescent tops in
σ such that the inversion top number of each letter b in g′ is the right embracing number of b
in σ. Rearranging the columns of τ ′ , so that the bottom row is in increasing order, we obtain
the permutation τ = Φ(σ) as the top row of the rearranged biword.
(2-31)k σ = nestk τ

Proof of Theorem 8. Given σ ∈ Sn , let τ = Φ(σ). It is easily checked that every column ji



in ff′ satisfies i < j and every column ji in gg′ satisfies i ≥ j. It follows that each letter
σi in g′ corresponds to a nondescent σi in σ and also a weak excedance σi in τ , that is, for
all 1 ≤ i ≤ n,
σi < σi+1 (1 ≤ i ≤ n − 1) or i = n ⇐⇒ σi ≤ τ (σi ).
(31)
Hence, ndes σ = wex τ . By definition, (2-31) σ is the sum of the right embracing numbers in
σ and the sum of the inversions in the words f ′ and g′ . If a pair (i, j) is an inversion in f ′
(resp. g ′ ), then we have τ (i) < τ (j) < j < i (resp. j < i ≤ τ (i) < τ (j)) and the pair (i, j) is
a nesting in τ . Thus
(2-31)k σ = nestk τ, ∀k ∈ [n].
Similarly,
(31-2)k σ = crosk τ,

∀k ∈ [n].

Also, by (40) and (29),
MAD σ = n − ndes σ + (31-2) σ + 2 (2-31) σ
= n − wex τ + cros τ + 2 nest τ = inv τ.
Finally, if k is a foremaximum in σ, then k must be a nondescent top as well as a nondescent
bottom, so k is in the two subwords g and g ′ . By definition, (31-2)k σ = 0. Therefore, the



column kk appears in gg′ , i.e., τ (k) = k. Conversely, if τ (k) = k, then the column kk

appears in gg′ and (31-2)k σ = 0. It implies that k is not a foremaximum in σ. Hence
fmax σ = fix τ .

Remark. Corteel [Cor05, Section 5] gave a similar bijection ΦC on Sn which transforms the
triple statistic (ndes, 31-2, 2-31) to (wex, nest, cros), while Steingrı́msson-Williams [SW07b,
Section 5] gave another one which transforms the triple statistic (ndes, 31-2, 2-31) to (n +
1 − wex, nest, cros). Other variations are given in [SS96]. The bijection Φ ◦ Φ−1
C : Sn → Sn
preserves the number of weak excedances and exchanges the number of crossings and the
number of nestings. A direct description of this bijection would be interesting.

triple statistic (wex, cros, nest) using Foata-Zeilberger's bijection. We show here that the
same bijection can be used to compute the generating function for the quintuple statistic
(wex, fix, cros, nest, inv). For σ ∈ Sn , let

We shall construct a sign-reversing involution φ on Sn (resp. ψ on D∗n ), which yields (47)
(resp. (48)). Letting σ = σ1 * * * σn ∈ Sn , an entry σi is called a double ascent (resp. double
descent) if σi−1 < σi < σi+1 (resp. σi−1 > σi > σi+1 ).

 16

HEESUNG SHIN AND JIANG ZENG

6.1. Involution φ on Sn . Let σ = σ1 . . . σn ∈ Sn with σ0 = σn+1 = 0. Let σm be the
largest integer (if any) such that σm is a double ascent or double descent in σ.
(1) If σm is a double ascent, then define
φ(σ) := σ1 . . . σm−1 σm+1 . . . σk−1 σm σk . . . σn ,
where k is a minimum index such that σk < σm and m < k. Thus
(31-2) φ(σ) = (31-2) σ

ndes φ(σ) = ndes σ − 1.

and

(2) If σm is a double descent, then define
φ(σ) := σ1 . . . σk σm σk+1 . . . σm−1 σm+1 . . . σn ,
where k is a maximum index such that σk < σm and k < m. Hence
(31-2) φ(σ) = (31-2) σ

and

ndes φ(σ) = ndes σ + 1.

(3) Otherwise, there exists no double ascent neither double descent in σ, so σ ∈ A′n .
Define A′n to be the set of fixed points of φ, that is, φ(σ) := σ on σ ∈ A′n .
Therefore, when the weights of σ is defined by (−1)ndes σ q (31-2) σ , the mapping φ is a signreversing involution on Sn with fixed point set A′n . Hence (47).
6.2. Involution ψ on D∗n . Let σ = σ1 . . . σn ∈ D∗n with σ0 = 0 and σn+1 = n + 1. Let σm
be the largest integer (if any) such that σm is a double ascent or double descent in σ.
(1) If σm is a double ascent, then define
ψ(σ) := σ1 . . . σk σm σk+1 . . . σm−1 σm+1 . . . σn ,
where k is a maximum index such that σk > σm and k < m. Note that k must exist
because σ ∈ D∗n has no foremaximum. Thus
(31-2) ψ(σ) = (31-2) σ − 1 and

ndes ψ(σ) = ndes σ − 1.

(2) If σm is a double descent, then define
ψ(σ) := σ1 . . . σm−1 σm+1 . . . σk−1 σm σk . . . σn ,
where k is a minimum index such that σk > σm and m < k. Note that k could be
n + 1. Therefore
(31-2) ψ(σ) = (31-2) σ + 1 and

ndes ψ(σ) = ndes σ + 1.

(3) Otherwise, there exists no double ascents or double descents in σ, so σ ∈ A′′n . Let A′′n
be the set of fixed points of φ, that is, ψ(σ) := σ on σ ∈ A′′n .
Therefore, when the weights of σ is defined by (−1/q)ndes σ q (31-2) σ , the mapping ψ is a signreversing involution on D∗n with fixed point set A′′n . So we have proved (48).
Remark. The involution ψ on D∗n keeps track of the statistic MAD, that is, MAD σ =
MAD ψ(σ) for all σ ∈ D∗n . It follows that

The involution φ on Sn does not work for (12). It would be interesting to find a combinatorial proof of (12).
